intro: Turnera oculata var. paucipilosa, commonly known as the "Mexican buttercup," is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a perennial shrub characterized by its woody stems and bright yellow, cup-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments such as forest understories. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and often have a distinctive white or yellowish marking. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes other flowering plants with showy blooms and often hairy foliage.
